node.title: The dodo had no predators in its native Mauritius. That was before the ships cameÂ
node.alt: A woman in a mask walks past rows of skeletons in a museum.
node.description: Has humanity learned its lesson after driving the dodo to extinction? With the environment and biodiversity still at risk, it doesn't seem so.
node.content:
["Has humanity learned its lesson after driving the dodo to extinction?With the environment and\u00a0biodiversity still at risk, it doesn't seem so.\u00a0\u00a0", "", "
The Oxford University Museum of Natural History is home to the best-preserved dodo in the world.(Getty Images: Jacob King/PA Images)
", "Inside the Oxford University Museum of Natural History, death is everywhere.", "A skeleton of a reindeer looks across\u00a0at the bones of a polar bear, a pig\u00a0and a rhinoceros, in the aptly named 'Skeleton Parade.'", "Nearby, rows of taxidermied animals gaze lifelessly at visitors from inside their glass cases.", "And in the depths of this grand museum, there's perhaps one of the most important dead animals in the world.", "It's actually several parts of one animal \u2014 there's a leathery, worn head,\u00a0a dissected foot\u00a0and a few feathers.", "Known as the 'Oxford dodo',\u00a0this specimen is the only surviving soft tissue remains of the extinct species.", "For some, the remains are a warning of humanity's disregard for nature;\u00a0for others, they evoke\u00a0hope that dodo DNA still exists for scientific study.", "But for Kash Sunghuttee, a British man with Mauritian heritage, it's much more complicated.", "\"I was in Oxford, I went to the museum and I just thought, what the hell is this?\" he says.", "", "Mr Sunghuttee's disbelief stemmed from the fact that before dodos became extinct, they were native to Mauritius.", "\"When you go to Mauritius, there's a museum with a dodo in it, but it's a fake dodo,\" he says.", "\"I thought, why does Oxford have the real dodo and Mauritius has the fake dodo? I was furious.", "\"Imagine that British bulldogs were extinct\u00a0and the only existing soft tissue specimen of the British bulldog was in Mauritius, while the UK had a fake one. English people would be on boats going there right now \u2026 It's the principle of the thing.\"", "So, how did these invaluable remains from a tiny island off the coast of Africa end up half a world away?", "", "
Mauritius is located off the the southeast coast of Africa.(Getty Images: Norbert Figueroa/EyeEm)
", "Mauritius is located in the Indian Ocean, around 2,000 kilometres from the south-east coast of Africa.", "The lush, sun-kissed island was uninhabited, before being claimed by the Dutch in 1598, then the French in 1715 and then the English in 1810.", "Today, around 1.3 million people live in Mauritius, with different cultural groups reflecting its various\u00a0colonial eras.", "Vikash Tatayah, the conservation director of the Mauritian Wildlife Foundation, says the long-dead dodo remains extremely popular there.", "\"We have restaurants named after the dodo \u2026 We have matches named after the dodo,\" he says.", "The famous flightless bird features on everything from the country's coat of arms to its banknotes.", "", "\"[The dodo weighed] around 15 to 20 kilos and was nearly a metre in height, so it would have been one of the largest birds of the time. If it was still alive today, we would probably be\u00a0farming it,\" he says.", "According to Mr Tatayah, the dodo had no predators in Mauritius and, as a result, was a \"very naive bird.\"", "This meant it was easy prey for the Europeans, along with the cats, rats and other introduced animals that came with them.", "Writings from the Dutch era mention dodos had no fear of humans, with colonists and sailors shooting one bird and the others nearby not even running away.", "", "\"When you combine habitat destruction, predation and hunting [of]\u00a0a species like a dodo which, as far as we know, laid just a single egg each year, this is a recipe for disaster, a recipe for a very rapid extinction,\" Mr Tatayah says.", "And that's exactly what happened.", "\"Prior to this, people thought that when an animal or plant went extinct,\u00a0you could find it on the next island or in the next forest or on the next continent.\u00a0\u00a0", "\"But with the dodo, they realised it's gone\u00a0\u2014 and it's gone forever.\"", "The dodo went extinct during the Dutch era of Mauritius, with the last sighting\u00a0in 1662.", "", "
The tiny island of Mauritius was uninhabited until it was occupied by\u00a0colonisers.\u00a0(Illustration: ABC/Teresa Tan; Map elements: Rawpixel/Jan Luyken.)
", "By the time the French claimed the island in 1715, there was no evidence the bird was still alive \u2014 and even some disbelief that it ever existed.", "So, the dodo was almost wiped from memory, years before the British took control of Mauritius.", "And yet, one ended up in Oxford.", "A small number of live dodos \u2014 maybe a dozen \u2014 were taken from Mauritius before they went extinct.", "Shipping records, diaries and other documents have fleeting references to dodos popping up in places like Hungary, Indonesia, and Japan.", "And at least one made the long voyage\u00a0to England.", "", "
A sketch of the Dutch arriving in Mauritius in the late 1500s, which features a dodo.(Getty Images:\u00a0Science & Society Picture Library)
", "In 1638, English theologian Hamon L'Estrange wrote that he was wandering the back streets of London, when he saw a sign hanging on a shop, reading \"strange fowle.\"", "For a small fee, Londoners could see a live dodo. So, Mr L'Estrange paid and entered.", "\"[It was] bigger than the largest turkey cock \u2026 but stouter and thicker and of a more erect shape,\" he wrote.", "Eighteen years later, there's another clue\u00a0in the writings of a gardener. But not just any gardener.", "", "
John Tradescant\u00a0acquired the Oxford dodo in the\u00a017th century.(Getty Images: Heritage Images)
", "", "
The Musaeum Tradescantianum was the first museum open to the public to be established in England.(Getty Images:\u00a0Print Collector)
", "John Tradescant, the gardener to King Charles II, collected natural curiosities. This included a dead bird which he called a \"dodar [sic] from the island of Mauritius\" which \"is not able to flie being so big.\"", "The Mauritian Wildlife Foundation's Mr Tatayah says, \"the dodo that was on show in London is most probably the one that the Tradescant family acquired.\"", "The Tradescant family, in addition to being gardeners for royalty, also set up the first public museum in England.", "Musaeum Tradescantianum housed all manner of curiosities \u2014 including the then-deceased\u00a0dodo \u2014 which were later gifted to Oxford University.", "In the years that followed, countless people saw the dodo at the Oxford museum.", "Among them was a maths lecturer by the name of Charles Dodgson, who would bring his friend's children on visits to the collection.", "This dodo would inspire Mr Dodgson to create a character of a dodo in a new children's book.", "Mr Dodgson's pen name was Lewis Carroll and among the children he brought along was a girl named Alice.", "", "\"What would really make the dodo popular [internationally] would be Alice in Wonderland,\" Mr Tatayah says.", "In 2018, the story of the Oxford dodo took a dramatic twist.", "The specimen was undergoing a form of CT scan at the University of Warwick when scientists noticed something odd.", "\"There were a couple of really dark spots, it was brushed off very quickly, because we assumed it might have just been some debris in the foam where we set it up for this scan,\" says Dr Jay Warnett.", "", "
The Oxford dodo is made up of several parts of the one long-dead bird.(Supplied:\u00a0Warwick University/Oxford University Museum of Natural History)
", "But they took another look and realised it was metal embedded in the bird's skull.", "\"The severity of how deep some of these pellets were embedded \u2013 this could only have happened through being shot,\" Dr Warnett says.", "The team was stunned.", "\"The first thing which occurs to you is, this was a money-maker and also a pet. You wouldn't shoot your own money-maker or pet,\" Dr Warnett says.", "\"So, the whole idea of where this dodo came from, the provenance story is now all up in the air.\"", "But palaeontologist Delphine Angst has a theory.", "\"The only reason I could think of is if the animal was very ill. And then they had to kill the bird rather than let it suffer for a long time,\" she says.", "\"But because we don't have the rest of the body, it's impossible to tell.\"", "", "
Jay Warnett was part of the team that discovered the Oxford dodo was shot.(Supplied)
", "", "
Palaeontologist Delphine Angst says\u00a0it's impossible to\u00a0know why the Oxford dodo was shot.(Supplied)
", "Dr Warnett says further tests could be undertaken to try and find out the \"chemical signatures\" of the pellets, which may offer clues to the shooting.", "But there's a hitch. The pellets are very deeply embedded\u00a0and extracting them could severely damage the sample.", "So further tests could potentially prove where the pellets came from, who actually killed this dodo and maybe even how it ended up in the UK.", "But doing so would possibly destroy the specimen.", "Mr Sunghuttee has thought a lot about the dodo since his visit to the Oxford museum.", "For him, the bird represents many things, but above all, it represents the catastrophic impact of colonisation on the environment, both intentional and unintentional.", "\"It's tempting to look at anything that's happened in the past and think there was a master plan, that all of the effects were predicted,\" he says.", "\"The extinction of the dodo wasn't part of a plan. The people that made the dodo extinct had no idea what they were doing.\"", "", "He says it's so easy to forget that the Earth itself has paid a price for our expansion over the seas.", "His thoughts are all the more poignant considering the climate and biodiversity crises the world is now facing.", "For Mr Tatayah, conservation efforts in his native Mauritius remain a constant battle.", "He's now working with another incredible creature: the giant tortoise.", "", "
British man\u00a0Kash Sunghuttee says the Oxford dodo doesn't belong in Oxford.(Supplied)
", "", "
Vikash Tatayah is on a mission to save the remaining wildlife in Mauritius.(Supplied)
", "These gentle giants can grow up to a metre tall and live for upwards of 200 years. And like the dodo, these animals have little, if any, fear of humans.", "\"I would say, sadly, most people have not learned the lessons of the dodo,\" Mr Tatayah says, after\u00a0recently visiting some giant tortoises in Mauritius.", "", "\"When you say the destruction was done 400 years ago, you can probably forgive the people at the time, because of a lack of knowledge, because they had to survive,\" he says.", "\"But while we can forgive the past generations, future generations will not forgive us for what we are doing to nature now and the actions that we are not taking.", "\"Conservation is not rocket science, but it needs dedication.\"", "This story comes from ABC Radio National's Stuff the British Stole podcast. Season two was co-produced with CBC Podcasts.
